text:
Thanks all - upgraded to jq-1.7.1  but still getting the same error for the moment. I'm going to keep looking for the error and try a few things to get it to work. Will share if i come across anything

If it helps we are currently on a linux server atm, so not MacOS. May need to switch to macOS if i keept running into the error. I feel it may be related to the IP/permissions perhaps

curl-ing simply <https://scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global/api/scan/v0/scans> gives me "Forbidden"

any restrictions on server regions? Currently housed in Sydney,AU

Also noting that I've got almost a clone ready to set up for our mainnet node (same infra / operating system etc, running jq-1.7) and am able to run the validation script on our Mainnet IP correctly as it produces the required list - just doesn't work when querying the Devnet list

text:
I've been wondering about the same thing recently.

When we first deployed the T-RIZE mainnet validator, it was with kubernetes and the docker-compose documentation was behind the kubernetes one.

Nowadays, they seem to be on par.

However, from our experience of running a testnet node with docker compose is that it seems to be rather unstable.

Anyway, I'm curious to read the input from others in this discussion

elements.text:

text:
Yes, it is possible to reach the applications. All you need to do is work with the configuration of the nginx container.

Here is he file splice-node/docker-compose/validator/nginx.conf from our testnet node. Please note that we still have to enable ssl (https) via a certificate, and as of now these are only accessible through non-encrypted http traffic

elements.text:
Yes, it is possible to reach the applications. All you need to do is work with the configuration of the nginx container.

Here is he file splice-node/docker-compose/validator/nginx.conf from our testnet node. Please note that we still have to enable ssl (https) via a certificate, and as of now these are only accessible through non-encrypted http traffic

text:
Reference from the whitepapaer
> The Global Synchronizer is decentrally operated by independent entities called Super Validators. The Global Synchronizer will be the first instance of a decentralized synchronization domain for the Canton Network but is not intended to be the only one. Third parties may set up their own decentralized Canton synchronization domains using the code available through Splice, a Hyperledger Lab.
So the question being how would connecting to lets say the mainnet and some other `decentralized synchronization domain`

elements.text: Reference from the whitepapaer

The Global Synchronizer is decentrally operated by independent entities called Super Validators. The Global Synchronizer will be the first instance of a decentralized synchronization domain for the Canton Network but is not intended to be the only one. Third parties may set up their own decentralized Canton synchronization domains using the code available through Splice, a Hyperledger Lab.
So the question being how would connecting to lets say the mainnet and some other
decentralized synchronization domain

text:
Folks, Check this out:

```Production validators, with the following caveats:

The default deployment is highly insecure. Authentication should be enabled as described in the authentication section.

There is no support for ingress from outside your machine, nor is there support for TLS. The deployment should be kept local to your machine only and not exposed externally.

Reliability & scalability: docker-compose will restart containers that crash, and the deployment supports backup&restore as detailed below, but a docker-compose deployment is inherently more limited than a cloud-based Kubernetes one.

Monitoring: The deployment, as opposed to a Kubernetes-based one, does not include monitoring.

For production settings, you should aim to keep your validator up and running constantly, in order to avoid losing out on rewards, and avoid issues with catching up on ledger state after significant downtime.```
SOurce:
<https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_compose.html#docker-compose-based-deployment-of-a-validator-node>

elements.text: Folks, Check this out:

Production validators, with the following caveats:

The default deployment is highly insecure. Authentication should be enabled as described in the authentication section.

There is no support for ingress from outside your machine, nor is there support for TLS. The deployment should be kept local to your machine only and not exposed externally.

Reliability & scalability: docker-compose will restart containers that crash, and the deployment supports backup&restore as detailed below, but a docker-compose deployment is inherently more limited than a cloud-based Kubernetes one.

Monitoring: The deployment, as opposed to a Kubernetes-based one, does not include monitoring.

For production settings, you should aim to keep your validator up and running constantly, in order to avoid losing out on rewards, and avoid issues with catching up on ledger state after significant downtime.
SOurce:

text: arguably these caviats can be worked on to be resolved or risk-managed

elements.text: arguably these caviats can be worked on to be resolved or risk-managed

text: And I believe that only scalability would be an issue with a docker-compose setup, but if minimal time is tolerated, it would not be an issue. And nothing stops the migration from docker-compose into a kubernetes node shall a node require.

elements.text: And I believe that only scalability would be an issue with a docker-compose setup, but if minimal time is tolerated, it would not be an issue. And nothing stops the migration from docker-compose into a kubernetes node shall a node require.

text:
the screenshot you posted looks good. IDK how to check on my end if yours is working, I think a SV has to do that.

The errors in the log are normal on a first start, it is just one container trying to connect before the other is ready and then waiting for the other container to start

elements.text:
the screenshot you posted looks good. IDK how to check on my end if yours is working, I think a SV has to do that.

The errors in the log are normal on a first start, it is just one container trying to connect before the other is ready and then waiting for the other container to start

text:
on the docker compose file, it is possible to add a delay to the start of a component, besides declaring what other containers are dependencies.

the dependencies only check if the other container has started, but it does not check if the application of the other container is ready to respond

elements.text:

the dependencies only check if the other container has started, but it does not check if the application of the other container is ready to respond

I'm attaching the logs as files for both the services. Can anyone please take a look and let us know if anyone has the similar issues before. Thank you
